text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with bacon and egg donuts that's
right we could have called these bacon
and egg beignets but it is a national
beignet day June 5th is national donut
day so that's what we're calling them
and besides if it's a sweet dough and
you fry it in America you're allowed to
call it a donut that's in the
Constitution but anyway let's go ahead
and get started with what is I think not
only the lightest variety of donut but
also one of the simplest to make so
let's head over to this stove where we
have a little bit of fresh cold water in
a saucepan which we're going to bring to
a simmer on medium high heat and to that
we're going to add a pinch of salt and a
giant chunk of butter we're also going
to sweeten this up just a touch with a
little bit of sugar as well as some
freshly grated nutmeg one of our classic
donut spices and then as soon as this
mixture starts to simmer what we'll do
is we'll turn it down to medium we'll
grab a wooden spoon and we'll dump in
some flour all at once and we will cook
that stirring until it's sort of all
comes together and this is one of those
techniques where if you haven't done it
before it looks like something's wrong
when you first start and you'll probably
think you screwed something up but you
didn't just keep stirring and eventually
we'll all come together and of course
I'm editing but this does happen pretty
quick so we'll just keep stirring it and
cooking it on medium until it all pulls
together into a very soft dough ball
that looks something like this and as
soon as that happens we'll take it off
the heat and transfer it into a mixing
bowl and at this point we'll give it a
little bit of vanilla before whisking in
our eggs but not quite yet because this
is too hot so what we want to do is sort
of break it up with a whisk and let it
sit there and cool for about five
minutes otherwise we might accidentally
get some scrambled eggs so like I said
we'll break that up and let it cool a
little bit before adding the first of
the two eggs we're going to incorporate
so we'll toss in a large egg and we'll
grab our whisk and we'll start mixing
and fair warning when you first start
mixing it it's not going to go very well
it's going to look terrible and it's
usually right about here where people
stop convinced that something's gone
horribly wrong and they email me telling
me my recipe is no good but all they
actually needed to do was keep whisking
because if he keeps stirring it will go
from something that looks very separated
and totally screwed up to something
smooth and sticky and we want to keep
mixing until it all bunches up on the
whisk that's how you know you're ready
for the second egg
so we'll clean off our whisk and we'll
repeat the same exact process with egg
number two and just like the first when
you first start mixing it's going to
look a little funky but just keep
stirring and stirring and eventually it
will incorporate and you'll end up with
something that looks like this and when
it does get to that point what we'll do
is we'll clean off our whisk we'll
scrape down our bowl and we will cover
that dough in plastic and we'll
refrigerate it for about an hour because
I do believe these fry up better if your
dough is nice and cold so the a key part
of our doughnuts is done and while
that's chilling in the fridge we will
move on to cook the bacon so I sliced up
about six strips of bacon which I added
to a cold pan which will place over
medium heat and we will cook that
stirring occasionally until the bacon is
nicely browned and all the fat is pretty
much rendered out okay so we don't want
anything flabby here so we want to cook
it at least this far at which point we
will drain that on some paper towel and
let it sit there until it's cool enough
to work with and by work with all we're
going to do is chop this up with a knife
nice and small and pro tip try not to
eat it all as you're chopping it that's
always a danger and by the way I'm going
to save a little bit of this bacon to
garnish the top with that would be
optional and then once our bacon has
been fried cooled and chopped up we'll
remove our cold eggy dough from the
fridge and we will add our bacon bits
and stir them in and I will admit as I
was doing this since I had never made
bacon and egg donuts before I was
actually a little concerned with how
these were going to fry up because I was
using a variety bacon that had a good
amount of sugar in it I was kind of
worried that the exposed bacon would
burn in the oil and as you'll see when
we first start frying it that looked
like it was going to happen but happily
as you will ultimately see when these
were all puffed up and brown they
actually looked really really good but
anyway that's what I was daydreaming
about as I was mixing this and once we
do have everything incorporated you know
what time it is
oh yeah it's time to make the donuts and
to form mine I'm going to use this
little sorbet scoop but if you want you
could just use a couple spoons and we're
going to go ahead and fry these at 350
degrees for about seven minutes and by
the way don't go anywhere because this
is going to be a very entertaining seven
minutes or so so when we first put them
in not much happens there's a lot of
bubbling and then there's less bubbling
and then they sort of start to brown and
kind of float and then a couple minutes
in something very interesting happens
they turn themselves over check it out
I'm actually doing that with my mind
actually I'm not is these expand the
center of gravity changes and they roll
over while two out of three ain't bad so
we'll give this one a little help
and as these cook the air inside is
going to expand and they're going to
kind of crack open all right you can see
how they're kind of split and open there
and they are going to significantly
increase in size and once that happens
it's very important you stand there with
the strainer and turn them often so that
they get a nice even browning and they
cook as uniformly as possible and the
bigger they puff the higher they're
going to sit up on the oil so if you're
not continuing to turn them they're
going to get browned in just one spot
and like I said we're going to cook
those for about seven minutes or until
they are fully puffed and pretty much
golden brown all over so we'll pull
those out of the oil and we do want to
serve these right away but we should
take a moment and let them drain for a
few seconds on some paper towels and
while mine we're doing that I was
inspecting the surface for possibly
overcooked bacon pieces but you know
what while they were dark they were
actually crispy and delicious so I guess
if you have some really really dark
pieces you could pick them off but I
thought these look great so I didn't but
of course that's up to you you are the
draymond Green of whether those darker
pieces of bacon are seen and also go
dubs and then once those have been
drained on some paper towels for a few
seconds we will plate up and serve these
piping hot with some maple syrup and for
this type of doughnut it is
traditionally powdered sugar but we are
doing sort of a breakfast theme here
plus Father's Day is coming up and these
would be great to surprise dad with and
of course dads really don't enjoy
powdered sugar it gets stuck in their
mustache I mean so does maple syrup but
at least you can't see it and then as I
mentioned I did save a little bit of
bacon for the top and those bacon and
egg donuts are done and call it
beginner's luck but these came out
really really good these just had a
beautiful textural contrast between that
crispy outside
and then the inside was kind of Iggy and
custardy yet still very Airy very light
very puffed and of course not to mention
all that bacon so I could not have been
more happy with how these came out
especially considering how simple and
easy that dough is but anyway that's it
whether you're going to make these to
celebrate national donut day or you're
going to make these on Father's Day to
show your dad how much you love them I
really do hope you give these a try soon
so head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
